Media playback is not supported this device Subscribe the BBC Sport newsletter to get our pick news , features and video sent your inbox .", "The \" witches' marks \" were often carved entrances buildings , including the house where Shakespeare was born and the Tower London . The symbols were believed to offer protection when belief witchcraft and the supernatural was widespread . But heritage agency Historic England says too little is known them . This Halloween it is calling people to document the marks , which can be found medieval houses , churches and other buildings , most commonly 1550 1750 . The symbols , which were intended to protect inhabitants and visitors buildings witches and evil spirits , took many forms , including patterns and sometimes letters . The most common type was the \" Daisy Wheel \" , which looked a flower drawn a compass a single endless line that was supposed to confuse and entrap evil spirits . They also took the form letters , such AM Ave Maria , M Mary or VV , Virgin Virgins , scratched medieval walls , engraved wooden beams and etched plasterwork to evoke the protective power the Virgin Mary . Known examples include several found Shakespeare 's birthplace Stratford-upon-Avon , Warwickshire , carved the cellar door where beer was kept , and the Tithe Barn , Bradford-on-Avon , Wiltshire , to protect crops . Others have been found caves , such the Witches' Chimney Wookey Hole , Somerset , which has numerous markings . Duncan Wilson , chief executive Historic England , said : \" Witches' marks are a physical reminder how our ancestors saw the world . \" They really fire the imagination and can teach us previously-held beliefs and common rituals . \" Ritual marks were cut , scratched or carved our ancestors' homes and churches the hope making the world a safer , less hostile place . \" They were such a common part everyday life they were unremarkable and they are easy to overlook , the recorded evidence we hold where they appear and what form they take is thin . \"", "It came the day the remains the boiler house were demolished and the search resumed three men killed when the building partially came . Sir Michael said vocational subjects would suit some pupils better . particular he questioned the academic subjects included the government 's Ebacc would be the best thing pupils who wanted to take apprenticeships when they left school . \" I can think youngsters , even the highest-performing schools , who will find it a problem and who would have been better suited to do English , maths and science and a range vocational subjects ,\" he told the magazine . June , the Education Secretary Nicky Morgan confirmed she wants all pupils to have to study the five traditional subjects included the Ebacc school performance measure . According Mrs Morgan the move would ensure all pupils received a rigorous academic education and avoid pupils disadvantaged backgrounds being put academic subjects . addition , the Conservative manifesto pledges schools which do not have 100 % pupils studying this set subjects GCSE should not be able to obtain Ofsted 's top rating \" outstanding \" . Both policies will be subject a government consultation later the autumn . Sir Michael told the TES he agreed more young people should be studying these subjects - but said the combination was not suitable everyone . The Association School and College Leaders , which represents secondary heads , welcomed Sir Michael 's challenge government policy . General Secretary Brian Lightman said the union shared his concerns . He said a recent survey the union found almost 90 % school leaders disagreed making these subjects compulsory all pupils . \" It is unfair young people to take a one-size-fits-all approach their education . \" We are concerned creative , technology and vocational subjects will be squeezed the curriculum . \" Mr Lightman said the union would urge ministers to make the choice GCSE subjects more flexible . Work Portsmouth 's jetty , built the 1920s and last upgraded the 1970s , has begun , upgrades expected to be completed next autumn . It forms part a \u00c2 \u00a3 100m infrastructure package to prepare the base the arrival the first carrier . HMS Queen Elizabeth measures 280m ( 300 yards ) long and can travel 500 miles ( 800km ) a day . Michael CecireForeign Policy Research Institute The 2014 Sochi Olympics were billed a way boosting the economy bringing tourism Abkhazia or sourcing materials construction , but the most noticeable effect was actually a source frustration : the expanded security cordon that penetrated the Russia-Abkhazia border . Born Glasgow , he moved the village his family 1973 . About 60 people , including members Gen Johnston 's family , gathered the unveiling the pump house the village green . Gen Johnston was commanding a mobile medical unit close the German-Dutch border April 1945 . British Triathlon say the quality the performance Gold Coast will be taken consideration as well the finishing positions . The Welsh athlete would need to finish ahead Stimpson and show Olympic medal-winning potential . Jenkins won the world title 2008 and 2011 , and represented Team GB two Olympic games . The second inquest was initially suspended September the CPS carried a review the case , concluding it was right not to bring any charges Mr Worthington .", "The concept will be known Vulcan , and it is expected to start operations 2019 . United Launch Alliance - the joint venture Boeing and Lockheed Martin - currently flies the Atlas and Delta rockets . These are routinely used to loft Nasa science probes , spy satellites and other US national security missions . time , both vehicles will be retired the new Vulcan components come stream . The first element to be introduced will be the first-stage booster , which will feature an all-new , all-American liquid-fuelled engine . This will enable ULA to end its use Russian-made RD-180 rocket motors \u2013 something Congress has mandated . Politicians Capitol Hill dislike the fact American national security missions are launched the aid Russian propulsion technology . ULA 's preference is to incorporate a liquid methane-oxygen power unit currently being developed Blue Origin , the space company run Amazon entrepreneur Jeff Bezos . When the new Vulcan booster makes its debut , it will initially be married the current Centaur upper-stage the Atlas . But early the 2020s , this too will be replaced a bespoke upper-stage that should give the new rocket a performance that allows it to exceed even the Delta IV Heavy \u2013 the biggest , most powerful rocket the world today , capable putting upwards 25 tonnes a low-Earth orbit . Critically , though , the Vulcan will be substantially cheaper to build and operate . \" A Delta IV Heavy today \u2019s launch rates costs about $ 400m , give or take , depending the mission and its complexity . I fully expect the Next Generation Launch System to be less half that ,\" said Tory Bruno , president and CEO United Launch Alliance . Some cost savings will be made recovering and reusing the engines the first-stage booster following a flight . The idea is separation the upper-stage , the engines would detach the propellant tanks and fall back Earth , deploying an inflatable shield to protect them burning re-entry the atmosphere . Parachutes would then deploy and a helicopter would swoop in to pluck the engines the air and return them safely the ground servicing and re-integration a new booster . ULA will not say how much the Vulcan development programme is costing , but it will run the billions dollars . ULA has to modernise , however . The priority status it has enjoyed government contracts is coming an end , and it is facing increasingly stiff competition \u2013 home , a bullish SpaceX company , whose low-cost rockets are winning favour Nasa and commercial satellite operators ; and abroad , where Europe and Russia are both moving new-generation rocket systems that aim to reduce their launch prices also .", "Steven Rodriguez , who was better known A $ AP Yams or Yamborghini , died aged 26 18 January Brooklyn 's Woodhull Medical Centre . He said : \" There 's no restriction the imports these very powerful lasers . \"", "The artificial intelligence system - LipNet - watches video a person speaking and matches the text the movement their mouths 93 % accuracy , the researchers said . Automating the process could help millions , they suggested . But experts said the system needed to be tested real-life situations . Lip-reading is a notoriously tricky business professionals only able to decipher what someone is saying 60 % the time . \" Machine lip-readers have enormous potential , applications improved hearing aids , silent dictation public spaces , covert conversations , speech recognition noisy environments , biometric identification and silent-movie processing ,\" wrote the researchers . They said the AI system was provided whole sentences it could teach itself which letter corresponded which lip movement . To train the AI , the team - Oxford University 's AI lab - fed it nearly 29,000 videos , labelled the correct text . Each video was three seconds long and followed a similar grammatical pattern . human testers given similar videos had an error rate 47.7 % , the AI had one just 6.6 % . The fact the AI learned specialist training videos led some Twitter to criticise the research . Writing OpenReview , Neil Lawrence pointed the videos had \" limited vocabulary and a single syntax grammar \" . \" it 's promising to perform well this data , it 's not really groundbreaking . the model may be able to read my lips better a human , it can only do so when I say a meaningless list words a highly constrained vocabulary a specific order ,\" he writes . The project was partially funded Google 's artificial intelligence firm DeepMind .", "the UK is still ' bold ' but ' dependable ' , ' outward looking ' and a bastion free trade . There are rules place . \" Slade continued : \" You ca n't just go spending \u00a3 5m here or there . Whatever we do it will have to be financial constraints . \"", "Next was found to have used a tax avoidance scheme called a rate-booster . The court ruled Next diverted UK profits foreign subsidiaries to claim tax relief overseas profits . Such schemes are a way which firms avoid corporation tax foreign profits that are then paid back the UK parent firm . rules designed to prevent double taxation company profits , firms were able to claim credit tax paid money they made overseas . But some companies were able to exploit the rules the creation artificial arrangements involving what HM Revenue & Customs ( HMRC ) referred \" complex circular movements money companies the same group , they can claim there has been double taxation \" . Known rate-booster schemes , this enabled companies to avoid corporation tax diverting profits made the UK foreign subsidiaries . The foreign subsidiary then paid tax those profits - often a lower rate corporation tax - the profits were paid back the UK parent company . Finally , the UK parent company received credits HMRC the tax already paid its subsidiary . a result , companies were able to claim far more tax had been paid their overseas profits was actually the case . Legal changes 2005 and 2009 mean rate-booster schemes are no longer possible or attractive , HMRC added . The Next case is the second to reach court , following a 2013 ruling P & O Ferries , the firm appealed the decision and an appeal judgement is outstanding . HMRC said \u00a3 130m tax was stake 20 rate-booster cases , which were awaiting the P & O and Next decisions . 70 rate-boosters have already been conceded companies that wanted to avoid going court . This has brought more \u00a3 500m tax , it added . HMRC 's director general business tax , Jim Harra , said : \" This case shows how HMRC takes effective action big businesses that try to avoid paying tax convoluted , artificial avoidance schemes . HMRC expects all businesses to steer well clear such schemes . \" a statement , Next said it had paid the tax owed HMRC \" some years ago \" and this had been fully accounted the time . The retailer described the dispute itself and HMRC \" a technical debate complex legislation \" which had now been superseded . It added current UK law generally allowed companies to \" repatriate their profits a tax charge \" .", "The \" bemusement park \" a derelict seaside lido Weston-super-Mare attracted thousands visitors when it opened last summer . Carbon permits are a mechanism designed to reduce carbon dioxide emissions , companies have to pay to emit C02 . A sharp drop demand energy has led a massive oversupply permits . Critics the EU 's Emissions Trading System also argue the European Union issued too many permits the first place . The EU has proposed freezing 900 million permits to tackle this oversupply . \" There are too many permits the recession ,\" said Isaac Valero , spokesman EU Climate Commissioner Connie Hedegaard . The price carbon recovered slightly Monday demand an auction 3.5 million permits was stronger expected . A weak carbon price undermines efforts to reduce C02 emissions . The price carbon needs to be a good deal higher 5 euros - some believe 25 and 30 euros - to provide an adequate incentive companies to cut emissions and invest cleaner technologies , experts say . The carbon market is central Europe 's efforts to meet its climate change target a 20 % reduction C02 emissions 1990 levels 2020 .", "The contractor , Smartty 's Management Limited , has been asked to return the excess payment , the government said . Earlier this year , 10-year-old Ying Ying mated naturally and was also artificially inseminated . However , the staff Ocean Park are unsure which method has resulted the successful pregnancy . Ying Ying was sent mainland China 's Sichuan province this spring to take part a breeding programme . The 100kg female - described the park \" inquisitive , active and vigilant \" - attempted to mate naturally two male pandas five different occasions and one the attempts was deemed successful . But to improve the chances a viable pregnancy , Ying Ying was also artificially inseminated . The privacy watchdog had previously said the transfers were protected the Safe Harbour trade agreement . But a fortnight ago the European Court Justice ruled the pact invalid . The ECJ said a consequence the Irish regulator was indeed required to examine Mr Schrems' complaint \" all due diligence \" and ultimately decide to suspend transfers it believed the firm was not providing an \" adequate level protection \" to protect people 's privacy . Following the ruling , the Irish data commissioner sought guidance the High Court how it should proceed , resulting the latest proceedings . Mr Schrems alleges whistleblower Edward Snowden 's leaks demonstrate Facebook - as well other technology companies - \" aids US spy agencies mass surveillance \" breach the EU 's Charter Fundamental Rights . Facebook strongly denies providing \" backdoor \" access the US intelligence agencies and says its data-transfer processes were reviewed the Irish watchdog as recently 2012 . The social network , whose European headquarters is Dublin , has requested permission to voice its case the High Court , but has yet to find it will be permitted to do so . \" We believe it is critical we join the proceedings we can provide accurate information our procedures and processes , as well to correct inaccuracies that already exist ,\" a Facebook spokeswoman told the BBC . Mr Schrems has previously cast doubt what information the California-based company might provide . \" Facebook is very likely bound ' gag orders' and is not allowed to confirm such cooperation US authorities ,\" he wrote earlier this month . \" Facebook spokespersons [ who comment the matter ] typically do not have the necessary security clearance to know such programmes themselves . \" The case could set a precedent that influences how other EU regulators handle complaints data sent US-based computer servers processing and storage . They were also members band Those Without , which toured Cambridge youth clubs and pubs 1963 and 1965 . They studied together the Cambridge School Art Barrett left London - and Mr Pyle began a career theatre set design . \" Syd 's sister said he liked roses ,\" said Mr Pyle . \" And there 'll be a striped colour theme , which fans will recognise . \" The artwork his first solo album is turquoise and orange , and Paul worked those colours . \" There 's also a nod Abbey Road 's crossing . \" The centrepiece will be a circular sculpture , depicting a teenage Barrett a bicycle , armed a guitar and a paint palette . \" This was the Syd I knew art school ,\" said Mr Pyle . \" The 18-year-old , the free wheeler . \" He was n't ambitious glory , just very creative and anarchic . He was very charismatic - and very , very talented . \" He described Barrett a \" celebrated son Cambridge \" , who returned the city and lived a recluse his death 2006 . They say it shows the divergence may have began 360 years ago . It also suggests Travellers are closely connected Irish settled people . The researchers found any genetic disparities Travellers and settled people the Republic are largely due them remaining genetically isolated several centuries and their numbers decreasing . It is thought there are about 30,000 people living the Republic Ireland who are members the Travelling community , representing 0.6 % the total population . Previously it had been thought Travellers had become displaced 1845 and 1852 a result the Great Famine . \" The findings confirm the Irish Traveller population has an Irish ancestry and this comes a time where the ethnicity Travellers is being considered the Irish state ,\" the Royal College Surgeons' Prof Gianpiero Cavalleri said . \" It is important to emphasise Irish Travellers show clear features a genetic isolate , they are genetically very close settled people Ireland . \" It is also interesting to observe the isolation Travellers settled people predates the Great Famine . \" However it 's important to emphasise our research estimates the beginning the social divergence the Travelling community , rather their origin . \" DNA samples 42 Irish Travellers were compared that 143 European Roma , 2,232 settled Irish , 2,039 British , 5,964 European and 931 individuals the rest the world the study . Its importance an oil exporting nation has made economic interdependence the West - where the main consumer demand is found - a necessity . This , turn , has led strong political and military relationships that times have been a source awkwardness both sides . It stands its espousal a puritan version Sunni Islam , including harsh punishments such public beheadings , and its restrictions women . Population 28.7 million Area 2.24 million sq km ( 864,869 sq miles ) Major language Arabic Major religion Islam Life expectancy 73 years ( men ) , 76 years ( women ) Currency Riyal Head state , prime minister : King Salman bin Abdulaziz al-Saud The Al Saud dynasty holds a monopoly political power . Saudi Arabia was established 1932 King Abd-al-Aziz and he has been succeeded various sons . King Salman bin Abdulaziz al-Saud ascended the throne January 2015 following the death his half-brother , King Abdullah . He has been part the ruling clique princes decades and is thought likely to continue the main thrusts Saudi strategic policy , including maintaining the alliance the United States and working energy market stability . Saudi investors are major players the pan-Arab TV industry , but the country has one the region 's most tightly-controlled media environments . The government openly acknowledges widespread internet filtering takes place . It targets \" pornographic \" , Islam-related , human rights and political sites . Saudi Arabia has the highest per-capita YouTube use any country the world . It is reportedly home more 40 % all active Twitter users the Arab region . Some key events Saudi Arabia 's history : 1932 - The areas controlled King Abd-al-Aziz are unified the name Kingdom Saudi Arabia . 1938 - Oil is discovered and production begins the US-controlled Aramco ( Arabian American Oil Company ) . 1960 - Saudi Arabia is a founding member Opec ( Organisation Petroleum Exporting Countries ) . 1973 - Saudi Arabia leads an oil boycott the Western countries that supported Israel the October War Egypt and Syria . Oil prices quadruple . 2001 11 September - 15 the 19 hijackers involved attacks New York and Washington are Saudi nationals . 2011 - '' Arab Spring '' protests ripple the region , Saudi troops participate crackdown unrest Bahrain . 2015 March - Saudi Arabia launches campaign air strikes Houthi rebels Yemen .", "The NSPCC 's Childline service said it counselled more 4,500 children the past year compared about 2,400 2011-12 . The act similarly protects the eggs and nests swans . It is an offence to take or possess the egg a wild mute swan , or to damage or destroy the nest a mute swan use or being built . The rise was notable men who have sex men . the same time , rates genital warts decreased , thanks a vaccination campaign . Rates sexually transmitted infections a group also went down slightly , totalling 434,456 . But experts say this could be fewer people came forward testing . Chlamydia was the most commonly diagnosed STI , accounting nearly half the cases diagnosed 2015 . Young people are routinely offered chlamydia screening , but only 13 % young men and 32 % young women were tested 2015 . The large fall genital warts - a 7 % drop - was seen young women , and experts say this was probably the national human papilloma virus vaccination programme . All girls aged 12 13 are offered the jab part the NHS childhood vaccination programme . The FPA charity 's chief executive , Natika Halil , said boys should be offered the vaccine too , which is something ministers are considering . Genevieve Edwards , Marie Stopes UK , said the statistics should \" set alarm bells ringing \" the availability sexual health services young people and men who have sex men . \" We have to keep a focus preventing sexual ill health , and providing prompt diagnosis and treatment those who need it ,\" she added . The losses will come Hewlett Packard Enterprise ( HPE ) , which is splitting the printer and PC business . The company says the cuts will save $ 2.7bn ( \u00c2 \u00a3 1.76bn ) annual costs , the plan will cost $ 2.7bn to carry . a meeting Wall Street analysts , chairman and chief executive Meg Whitman said : \" We 've done a significant amount work the past few years to take costs and simplify processes and these final actions will eliminate the need any future corporate restructuring . \" The new structure proposed Ms Whitman sees HP Enterprise focusing primarily businesses and government agencies , and the PC and printing divisions the consumer market . The company currently has more 300,000 employees . \" The number is sadly larger some people might have expected , but I think it 's a reflection how much trouble HP has been having its services ,\" said Charles King , analyst the Silicon Valley IT consulting firm Pund-IT . \" I 'm frankly not sure HP is finished the layoffs . \" The company will not say where the cuts will fall , but part the plan involves changing the nature the workforce . The proportion workers what HPE calls \" low-cost locations \" is expected to rise 42 % now 60 % 2018 . The tech company has struggled the last decade to keep changing demands customers move away desktop computers . However , Hewlett-Packard is still one the world 's largest technology companies , revenues this year expected to top $ 50bn . The company famously started life a Palo Alto garage California 1939 and grew to be the guiding light what became known Silicon Valley . Its fortunes started to decline a series expensive and much criticised acquisitions including Compaq $ 25bn 2002 , consultants EDS $ 14bn 2008 and Autonomy $ 11bn 2011 . 2012 it lost its position the world 's leading supplier PCs Lenovo . The share price peaked the height the dot.com boom 2000 , and , two surges 2007 and 2010 , it has lost some 60 % its value then .", "Yorkshire Ambulance Service ( YAS ) figures show medics spent 32,000 hours waiting A & E departments 2015-16 compared 16,000 2014-15 . YAS said waiting time \" was one the most significant issues \" it faced . A shortage available hospital beds has been given one the problems causing knock-on delays A & E . Dr David Macklin , Executive Director Operations YAS , said handover waiting times were \" a system problem \" the NHS , not just Yorkshire , and said blame could not be attached individual hospitals . \" We have numerous occasions where we have multiple vehicles queued hospitals ,\" he said . \" Emergency departments Yorkshire are working incredibly hard to manage their demand and that means sometimes ambulances are queuing . \" Patients who are not seriously injured may need to wait . \" Professor Keith Willett NHS England said the increase waiting times was \" concerning \" and added there were \" a multitude reasons \" the rise . \" One the biggest problems is the pressure the beds the hospital ,\" he said . \" That 's the hospitals are finding it increasingly difficult to move patients and their care back the community . \" The figures were supplied a Freedom Information request the BBC . Just five hospitals - one each East , South and West Yorkshire and two North Yorkshire - accounted about 70 % the total waiting time . The handover time is counted only 15 minutes have elapsed A & E . The number hours spent the YAS handover patients was 12,000 2013-14 and about 16,000 2014-15 . It added his funeral will be private , a memorial service to be held a later date . Hogwood worked many leading orchestras the world and was considered one the most influential exponents the early-music movement . The conductor founded the Academy Ancient Music ( AAM ) 1973 and directed the academy six continents some 30 years . The AAM also made more 200 CDs , including the first-ever complete cycle Mozart symphonies period instruments . his most famous recordings include the 1980 version Handel 's Messiah Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson , which was named BBC Music Magazine one the top 20 recordings all time . Hogwood studied keyboard Cambridge University Rafael Puyana and Mary Potts and later Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt . His first positions were a keyboard player and musicologist the Academy Saint Martin-in-the-Fields Sir Neville Marriner , and was a founder member the Early Music Consort London . He was the artistic director the King 's Lynn Festival and Boston 's Handel and Haydn Society . He was also a tutor Harvard University , honorary professor music the University Cambridge and a professor-at-large Cornell University the US . \" Christopher had extraordinary generosity spirit ,\" Christopher Purvis , honorary president the AAM , said . \" He was a great ambassador historically informed music , the movement which he was a founder . And he was happy to see the orchestra he founded develop and grow he stepped director . \" The AAM 's music director Richard Egarr added : \" I am deeply saddened the news Christopher 's passing . Christopher provided a fantastic legacy me to build when I joined 2006 and I know he will be greatly missed all who knew and worked him . \" Speaking Sean Rafferty Radio 3 's In Tune , soprano Dame Emma Kirkby said : \" Some the best players that now lead orchestras all the world , they started him . \" Chris was a natural academic , an incredibly clever man . He had an amazing capacity to absorb information all kinds and a really sure sense how things would be he really tried to reproduce conditions ... a very genial person . \" David Thomas Trinity Laban Conservatoire Music and Dance , London added : \" He always said I want the music to speak itself it can , it 's good enough , it will\u00e2 \u20ac\u00a6 a very pleasant and lovely man . \"", "Dana was transported the Al-Mawa reserve Turkey four other lions , two bears and two tigers a three-month operation organised the animal welfare charity Four Paws . Dr Amir Khalil , a vet who accompanied the animals , told the Associated Press Sunday an ultrasound performed Turkey had shown she was carrying two . However , he warned the second cub might already have been born dead and been eaten Dana . Its fate will not be known another ultrasound is carried Monday . Four Paws said its team had initially been very concerned Dana would accept or kill Hajar the enormous stress she had endured . \" But luckily that was n't the case . The site is known Two Women Sitting Down and is Bootu Creek , north Tennant Creek . OM Manganese was fined A $ 150,000 ($ 134,000 ; \u00c2 \u00a3 88,000 ) . Peter Toth , CEO OM Holdings , which owns OM Manganese , said : \" The company never intended to harm , damage or disrespect the sacred site . \" \" We sincerely regret the damage and the hurt caused and I unreservedly apologise the site 's custodians and traditional owners ,\" he said . Two Women Sitting is associated Australia 's Kunapa people . OM Manganese was accused causing the collapse part the site , including a distinctive rocky outcrop known the Horse 's Head , July 2011 . Prosecutors told the Darwin Magistrates Court the company performed explosive blasting close the site to break ground , Australian broadcaster ABC reported . The company was permitted to mine the area , but was advised to steer clear sacred sites , and was warned early 2011 cracks were appearing rocks the Bootu Creek site , the broadcaster said . Dr Ben Scambary , chief executive officer the Aboriginal Areas Protection Authority , said the site was great significance Australia 's indigenous people . \" This site ... relates a dreaming story a marsupial rat and a bandicoot who had a fight bush tucker [ native Australian bush food ],\" he said . \" the creation ancestors fought , their blood spilled , turning the rock a dark-red colour that is now associated manganese . \" Kunapa community representative Gina Smith said : \" It will always remain a sacred site us , but it has been ruined and we do n't know what to do this has never happened the old people . \" It has been there thousands years part our culture and our story . \" Indigenous Australians believe the land is the mother creation , and is a living , breathing mass full secrets and wisdom , the BBC 's Phil Mercer Sydney reports .", "K Prithika Yashini , who was born male but underwent gender reassignment surgery , applied to become a police sub-inspector the southern state .
